>Hello,

Welcome!

>I have a class which is responsible for deciding which email template to 
>use
>based on some complex business rules. The selected template is never stored
>in the class itself (this is a singleton object). Instead, it's passed to
>another method in another class which populates the template with dynamic
>data and sends the email out.

You may need to be more concrete about your design. Class names might help.

Still, your EMailTemplateDecider must have a method -- maybe it's private -- 
like "selectTemplate" or "selectTemplateDescriptor". In other words, it must 
have a way of mapping -- however complex the map may be -- some input to a 
template or template descriptor or template ID. Simply make assertions on 
the correctness of that mapping.

EMailTemplateDecider emtd = new EMailTemplateDecider();
assertEquals("templateA", emtd.selectTemplate(someInput));
...

Perhaps that method should be public and your "decider" is doing too many 
things.

BTW: Do you really need a singleton? Give this article a quick read to be 
sure.

http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/components/library/co-single.html

JBR.
